data.text: Best Tips for Weight/Space Saving on Ultralight Tours/Bikepacking
Those who tour/bikepack ultralight, please share your best weight/space saving tips and tricks. Newbie here, still trying to work out my gear.
I use storage cubes from eagle creek try to shave weight in the gear department but that can get expensive
data.author: Dana Williams

data.text: I'd say the best thing to do is just keep trying out your gear/setup on local one nighters. That way you'll get to see what you need, what you are not using and which is the preferred way to pack. I tend to pack all things for sleeping away in a bag which won't be touched through the day. Use dry bags as compartments for different, selections of gear, i.e cooking, cycling clothes, off bike clothes, rain clothes quick access etc
data.author: Jamie Ablitt

data.text: Before packing spread out all of your gear and ask yoursef "what do I sincerely need". You might also divide it to catogories like - things that are a must, things that I rather have, and things that would be cool to have. And then you will find yourself diminishing some stuff. For food its all about not worring too much and checking the filling of supplys you will have on your road.
data.author: Yoam Gelkopf

data.text: Just a credit card is the lightest you can go
data.author: Edward Gregory

data.text: Practice and refine. I was once told you will always fill the bag space you have. So try seeing if you can fit your kit into smaller/ less bags. Most people don‚Äôt start out ultralight, they whittle their gear down to get there.
data.author: Kenny Maddux

data.text: Every situation is different. My first question is what's your financial status. Can you afford to buy new clothes instead of washing. If you have a week with no rain in the forecast can you chuck the tent and just buy a new one when needed. Or are you tough enough to endure the elements to save the weight

data.text: tents, clothes. How many undie you want to carry. I rode from Cleveland Ohio to southern Florida without a tent about 30 days but I wouldn't recommend it
data.author: Teddy Ubber

data.text: Teddy Ubber I have no issue with going minimal. It‚Äôs viewing gear as disposable that feels in need of a reset.
data.author: John Knapp

data.text: Look into what ultralight backpackers do, the gear generally crosses over pretty well. Tons of YouTube and other resources there. Then like was mentioned above work through your kit until you are happy with it. It all comes down to how comfortable are you being uncomfortable. Also there are some things that just have weight on the bike, you can minimize them only so far that being tools and spares.
data.author: Dave Mitchell

data.text: Fork mounts, no panniers/rear rack. Make good use of the inner frame. ie; frame bag or 2 bottles. only wool clothing. better if food is all together. Lightweight riding/hiking rain jacket. I have a berghaus. lightweight down or synthetic jacket, I have a Mont synthetic. Tarp, not a tent. My thoughts.
data.author: Tom Cockerton

data.text: I don't care about weight when I'm bike touring, bikepacking I do. I carry everything I need, because deep in the desert there is nothing, only sand and waste, I'll get used to the weight, This is for long trips of thousands of kilometers for months, As for short trips, it is better to go lightÿå "bikepacking"

data.text: Make sure you don‚Äôt leave behind essentials If you get hypothermia you‚Äôre trip is over. But also don‚Äôt bring what you won‚Äôt need. Mostly after every trip as you‚Äôre unpacking, check if you used it (except first aid and bike repair). Check if it would have kept you alive (my day hiking above tree line pack is filled with things I hope to never need, but the 1% of time I need them I really need them) How many days can you stand to wear same socks? I‚Äôve had merino socks completely rigid but still comfortable after a few minutes and no feet issues.
data.author: Neil Wortley

data.text: the wisest move I might make towards ultralight is to reduce the size of my midsection.
data.author: Tom Adagio Sisk

data.text: I'm touring right now, 1,000kms through Europe with this, and despite this being my fourth or fifth tour I've still overpacked about 1/2kg. My main tip is to decide what to pack a week before you travel, lay it on a floor/spare bed/sofa and over the course of the week remove any duplication. You only really need one of anything: you can wash it. You need stuff to stay warm, dry, depending on the weather you're likely to encounter. You only need food if you're going places where there's no shops. You only need camping gear if there's no hotels.
data.author: Michael Bryant

data.text: There is no magic pill. Just think every item through. You can carry "heavy" stuff like panniers, a chair, and a free standing tent and still have a 40 pound bike. Clothing is the area that requires the most thought for me, especially in the off season. It's real easy to bring too much clothes.

data.text: Talk to any Tandem riders, they need to get 2 people‚Äôs stuff into the same space as a single solo rider.

data.text: Merino baselayers and clothes are great. Lots of warmth formthe bulk and weight, wash and dry easily, wick sweat and don‚Äôt smell too bad, so tou don‚Äôt need to wash too much. Also, with clothes roll and compress as you roll, makes them smaller, you can use elastic bands or elastic hairbands to keep them rolled

data.text: Plan on a motel overnight once a week. Hand wash all your clothes and hang them up overnight to dry. Many motels include an iron for those who need to get rid of wrinkles.

data.text: Not sure if this qualifies as ultralight - last month I did 2,000 miles with - light 40F down sleeping bag, silk liner, thermarest neoair xtherm pad, and a tent footprint below. Started the trip with a tent, used it only one day, shipped it home along the way. But then, mosquitoes and ants were my friends every night. - 2 bibs, one short sleeve jersey, one long sleeve one, light Gore jacket. Each bib used for 2 days then I wash in whatever sink I find. One civilian trousers and a T-shirt. - Tubus airy Ti rack and Arkel dry-lite panniers. And a tent bag with Voil√© straps in front. One pannier was used for gear, the other contained mostly food - I eat a lot. Like, really a lot when I bike.
data.author: Pierre Moreels

data.text: No stove. Cooked food is easy to find. Less clothes than you think you will need.

data.author: Rob Peters

data.author: Eric Yantis

data.text: unfortunately no accommodations out in the backcountry üòÅ
data.author: Megan Rose

data.text: Weekend overnights. Even midweek overnights if you can take a shower before work/work at a job where you can be sweaty. Every time you come back home, sort your stuff into three piles: 1.) "Used every day": this one should include your shelter, bike, riding kit, et cetera. 2.) "Was nice to have": items you used once or twice, like a stove on a hot weather trip. 3.) "Didn't use at all": anything left over. DO NOT put your flat kit or first aid kit in this pile, even if you didn't use them. Once you've done that a few times, you'll have a good idea of what you actually NEED on any given trip and can start looking at upgrades for those items to make them smaller/lighter/better performing. And you can add luxuries back in as you desire them, since you now have more room on the bike. Hope it helps!
data.author: John Almond

data.text: this is good advice! Should have done that after my last trip. Will do so after the next trip I have coming up in a couple weeks.
data.author: Megan Rose

data.text: Biggest space savers: Using a down quilt, not putting your sleeping bag/quilt in a stuff sack before it goes in your drybag/pannier, folding your clothes, using a clothes layering system with merino undies, a daily wash and deodorant cream. You won't need more than one of each item of clothing plus base layers for sleeping (and laundry). Biggest weight savers: Water management! Careful planning lets you get away with much less water. A gasoline stove means you can carry much less fuel because you can get it in most places. Learning more one pot recipes lets you go without a plate/bowl/second pot. Buy fresh produce for the meals closest to your resupply points and dried products for the meals which you will carry longer. A foldable backpack gives you more short term capacity for those days when you have only a few km from a shop to your campsite. Repackaging food right after purchase often makes sense (eggs go into a plastic bottle, oil goes from a glass into a plastic bottle, porridge/muesli ingredients all go into one ziplock bag, cardboard stays behind) and means you will carry less trash when you're out for a few days.
data.author: Felix Alpajim

data.text: Silnylon (such as sea to summit) drybags (Ultra-Sil for clothing) with one Lightweight drybag for washing/wet. It can be done with the Ultra-Sil bags, but the LW drybags perform better....Campsuds Citronella soap. 4Monster XXL camp towel. Look up "drybag laundry", it can be a lifesaver. The Campsudz soap can be used to wash your body, clothes, dishes or really anything..requires very little soap to water ratio. One-pot meals/cooking. titanium cookpot with at least 750ml capacity. I really recommend at least 1L, $20 butane stove off Amazon, and inexpensive butane bottle. Extra-long titanium spork. Everything will fit in the cookpot including a spare lighter except for the long spork, but will pack small and light...and inexpensive cook system. I do a lot of quinoa, rolled oats and my go-to for coffee is Nescafe Classico premixed with with creamer/sweetener in a ziploc bag. Most things that aren't camping equipment or clothes go in ziplok freezer bags. I do carry a Sea to Summit X-bowl because it doubles as a cutting board for dinner meals. If you want a superlight compact tent that doesn't cost Big Agnes or Nemo money, look at the REI Flash Air 1. It isn't freestanding, but only one pole and insanely light and compact packsize. For sleeping pad/bag/quilt, you just have to decide what works for you....sleep temp is personal preference, but I would choose to go warmer than colder for the pad.....I use a Sea To Summit Etherlite XT Insulated most of the time as it lets me pack a lighter sleeping bag and still remain comfortable. I am a side-sleeper so the 4" thick mattress is very welcome! The only other bit is choice of clothing. A good puffy jacket is quite good, but North Face has some synthetic paints that are extremely light and pack incredibly small for their comfort. Also if you go on Amazon and look for "Packable shoes", if you're like me and wear SPDs....these are amazing off the bike. I have a pair that roll up and fit in a jersey pocket even size9 mens. Used them last night on a "social" road ride once we go to the watering hole. Very comfortable, light and packable for off the bike. I guess considered "water shoes" but they retain water when wet....just slip-ons.

data.author: Jason Graham

data.text: I am fat. So the best option-but the hardest - would be lose a ton of weight. As for you. TARP! Not a tarptent, not a tent, just a tarp. I have travelled all over kingdom-come with just a tarp and been in major rain storms just fine. A quilt is lighter than a sleeping bag. I love hammocks, a simple DIY Speer style is easy to make, cheap and light. but you will be adding weight with that.
data.author: TC Rboert Dawson

data.text: I am interested in learning about lightening my wheelset so that my bike weight is more manageable to me post accident. To see whether it is worthwhile to make a big investment in that. - I used to do some heavy and some lighter bike packing, but major injuries have created a need for reducing weight. This information might also be useful for the author of this post. And I figure some people on here might have first-hand experience with getting a carbon wheel set...
data.author: Kira Davis

data.text: I have 2 sets of wheels for my bike. One set is the stock set made by Co-Motion for touring. It is really heavy. The other set is a carbon MTB set and much lighter weight. I haven‚Äôt actually weighed them, but I can say the lighter set makes my bike feel so much easier to lift. It‚Äôs a noticeable difference.

data.text: Put a piece of tape on each piece of gear, when you use that piece of gear take the tape off. After a week or two take a look at the gear that still has tape on it and really consider if you need it or not.

data.author: Lindsey Hamma

data.text: Go on a diet. The heaviest part of the bike is you...
data.author: Anders du Ton

data.text: If in the market for a tent - see if they have options for poles with smaller sections. I just bought a one-man tent. Poles were standard 3 pieces and optionally 5 pieces. Both shock-corded. The reason it matters is pole storage for bike touring/packing is always a hassle for standard-length poles. I do think Big Angus offers the smaller pole option and I hope it catches on. The 1-man tent I just bought was a 6-moon design and I am happy I paid an upcharge for the 5-section pole versus the standard 3. Just a tip for packing your tent system in a shorter space.
data.author: Peter Diotte

data.text: yes, I have the Nemo Dragonfly Bikepack tent and the short poles are great! I have a tiny frame so space is always at a premium.
data.author: Megan Rose

data.text: If bike touring in the US - you can buy whatever you forgot and mail home stuff you aren‚Äôt using. We all overpack. Lay it all out and remove at least 10%. You don‚Äôt need as many clothes as you think. Convertible pants can count as a pair of shorts too. Find other twofers. Sun sleeves can eliminate need for long sleeve shirt. 2 kits are plenty. My mentor goes with 1 kit, but I draw the line‚Ä¶. Riding shoes and lightweight Crocs or equivalent. My preference - one spare tube and patch kit, a hand pump and no cartridges. I don‚Äôt carry a cook kit. Also - try to reduce as you are - but this isn‚Äôt backpacking - a few extra pounds on a bike doesn‚Äôt matter - especially if it‚Äôs a comfort item. For example - I don‚Äôt take anything that requires a belt - but, if your fav shorts requires a belt - take it. Tarp only tent works - but depends on where traveling and time of year. Also - sleeping bag might be optional - just go with a liner and use a puffy jacket if it drops in temp. Also - get a half size air mattress - shoulder to butt is adequate vs full size (either air or pad mattress).
data.author: Peter Diotte

data.text: One other recommendation. Pack your bike like you would for your trip and do a quick overnighted - 40 miles out and 40 back. Camp. You‚Äôll learn a lot and tweak your load guaranteed.
data.author: Peter Diotte

data.text: I use a vacuum pump to evacuate all air before sealing the panniers.
data.author: Graeme Maher

data.text: I bring one extra set of clothes, and wash them as neededÔøº. Also, no stove. Just bring food you don‚Äôt have to cook. I‚Äôve had a lot of good luck with tortillas instead of bread.ÔøºSaves a lot of spaceÔøº.
